""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'The\n            Company (through its subsidiaries) provides turn-key wireless infrastructure services for wireless carriers,\n            tower companies and equipment manufacturers, and distributes and services a comprehensive line of\n            electronics and hardware for the telecommunications industry. The Company was incorporated under the laws of\n            Oklahoma in September 1989 as “ADDvantage Media Group, Inc.”\xa0 In December 1999, its name\n            was changed to ADDvantage Technologies Group, Inc. In 2019, the Company moved its headquarters from Broken\n            Arrow, Oklahoma to Carrollton, Texas and acquired Fulton Technologies, Inc. (“Fulton”) on\n            January 4, 2019, which established the Company’s Wireless Infrastructure Services segment. The\n            Company’s Telecommunications segment operates through its subsidiaries, Nave Communications Company\n            (“Nave”) and ADDvantage Triton, LLC (“Triton”).'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:10pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': ""Our\n            wireless infrastructure subsidiary provides services such as wireless macro site development, distributed\n            antenna systems, small cells and project management expertise with national and regional scalability.\n            Fulton's expertise includes site modifications, tower retrofits, including 5G, civil construction, tower\n            erection, utility installation and testing, site acquisition including leasing, zoning and permitting,\n            design and A&E.""}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:10pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': ""For our\n            telecommunications subsidiaries, we sell new, surplus-new and refurbished equipment that we purchase in the\n            market as a result of telecommunications system upgrades or overstock supplies.\xa0 We maintain one of the\n            industry's largest inventories of new and used equipment, which allows us to expedite delivery of\n            system-critical products to our customers. In addition, we offer our customers decommissioning services for\n            surplus and obsolete equipment, which we in turn process through our recycling program. In response to these\n            declarations and the rapid spread of COVID-19, federal, state and local governments have imposed varying\n            degrees of restrictions on business and social activities to contain COVID-19, including quarantine and\n            “stay-at-home” or “shelter-in-place” orders in markets where we operate. Despite\n            these “stay-at-home” or “shelter-in-place” orders, we are classified as an essential\n            business due to the services and products we provide to the telecommunications industry. Therefore, we\n            continue to operate in the markets we serve, but most of our back-office and administrative personnel were\n            working from home through September 30, 2020. Although we can continue to operate our businesses, our\n            revenues have slowed, especially in our Wireless segment, due to the carriers slowing down various wireless\n            tower projects. We have not experienced a material disruption in our supply chain to date; however, we\n            expect COVID-19 could materially negatively affect the supply chain, customer demand for our\n            telecommunications products or further delay wireless carriers’ infrastructure build plans in the\n            coming months as a result of the disruption and uncertainty it is causing. There is considerable uncertainty\n            regarding the extent to which COVID-19 will continue to spread and the extent and duration of governmental\n            and other measures implemented to try to slow the spread of COVID-19, such as large-scale travel bans and\n            restrictions, border closures, quarantines, shelter-in-place orders and business and government shutdowns.\n            Restrictions of this nature have caused, and may continue to cause, us, our subcontractors, suppliers and\n            other business counterparties to experience operational delays.'}}, {'@style': 'text-align:justify', 'span': {'br': None}}, {'@style': 'text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'In\n            response to COVID-19, we have taken a variety of measures to ensure the availability of our critical\n            infrastructure, promote the health and safety of our employees, and support the communities in which we\n            operate. Based on these factors, we make capital investment decisions that we believe will\n            support our long-term growth strategy. Depending on the timing and scope of these opportunities, we may need\n            to seek additional funding to finance the necessary working capital for such opportunities.'}}, {'@id': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'The\n            preparation of financial statements in conformity with United States generally accepted accounting\n            principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets\n            and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements\n            and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.\xa0 We base our estimates\n            and judgments on historical experience, current market conditions, and various other factors we believe to\n            be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the\n            carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.\xa0 Actual\n            results could differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.\xa0 The most\n            significant estimates and assumptions are discussed below.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:10pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Inventory\n            Valuation'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:10pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'For our\n            Telco segment, our position in the telecommunications industry requires us to carry relatively large\n            inventory quantities relative to annual sales, but it also allows us to realize high overall gross profit\n            margins on our sales.\xa0 We market our products primarily to telecommunication providers,\n            telecommunication resellers, and other users of telecommunication equipment who are seeking products for\n            which manufacturers have discontinued production or cannot ship new equipment on a same-day basis as well as\n            providing used products as an alternative to new products from the manufacturer.\xa0Carrying these large\n            inventory quantities represents our largest risk.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:10pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'We are\n            required to make judgments as to future demand requirements from our customers. We regularly review the\n            value of our inventory in detail with consideration given to rapidly changing technology which can\n            significantly affect future customer demand.\xa0 For individual inventory items, we may carry inventory\n            quantities that are excessive relative to market potential, or we may not be able to recover our acquisition\n            costs for sales that we do make.\xa0\xa0In order to address the risks associated with our investment in\n            inventory, we\xa0review inventory quantities on hand and reduce the carrying value when the loss of\n            usefulness of an item or other factors, such as obsolete and excess inventories, indicate that cost will not\n            be recovered when an item is sold.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:10pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Our\n            inventories are all carried in the Telco segment and consist of new and used electronic components for the\n            telecommunications industry.\xa0Inventory is stated at the lower of cost or net realizable value, with\n            cost determined using the weighted-average method.\xa0Net realizable value is the estimated selling price\n            in the ordinary course of business, less reasonably predictable costs of completion, disposal, and\n            transportation.\xa0 At September\xa030, 2020, we had total inventory, before the reserve for excess and\n            obsolete inventories, {'@style': 'margin-top:10pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'inventories\n 'margin-top:10pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Management\n            judgments and estimates are made in connection with establishing the allowance for doubtful accounts.\n            Specifically, we analyze the aging of accounts receivable balances, historical bad debts, customer\n            concentrations, customer credit-worthiness, current economic trends and changes in our customer payment\n            terms.\xa0 Significant changes in customer concentration or payment terms, deterioration of customer\n            credit-worthiness, or weakening in economic trends could have a significant impact on the collectability of\n            receivables and our operating results.\xa0 If the financial condition of our customers were to\n            deteriorate, resulting in an impairment of their ability to make payments, an additional provision to the\n            allowance for doubtful accounts may be required.\xa0 The reserve for bad debts was $250,000 and $150,000\n            at September\xa030, 2020 and September\xa030, 2019, respectively. Goodwill is not amortized and is tested at least\n            annually for impairment. We perform our annual analysis during the fourth quarter of each fiscal year and in\n            any other period in which indicators of impairment warrant additional analysis. Goodwill is evaluated for\n            impairment by first comparing our estimate of the fair value of each reporting unit, with the reporting\n            unit’s carrying value, including goodwill. Our reporting units for purposes of the goodwill impairment\n            calculation are the Wireless segment, Nave and Triton.'}}, {'@style': 'text-align:justify', 'span': {'br': None}}, {'@style': 'text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Management\n            utilizes a discounted cash flow analysis to determine the estimated fair value of each reporting unit.\n            Significant judgments and assumptions including the discount rate, anticipated revenue growth rate, gross\n            margins and operating expenses are inherent in these fair value estimates. As a result, actual results may\n            differ from the estimates utilized in our discounted cash flow analysis. The use of alternate judgments\n            and/or assumptions could result in the recognition of different levels of impairment charges in the\n            financial statements.'}}, {'@style': 'text-align:justify', 'span': {'br': None}}, {'@style': 'text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Due to\n            our continued operating losses and the uncertainties surrounding the COVID-19 pandemic on the overall\n            economy and the resulting impact on our Company, we determined that there were indicators to warrant us to\n            test goodwill for impairment at March 31, 2020. We calculated a fair value using the income approach of both\n            Nave and Triton to determine if the fair value exceeded their respective carrying values. For both Nave and\n            Triton, the fair value for each was less than their respective carrying values after considering the\n            intangible asset impairment. Therefore, we recorded an impairment charge of $4.8 million in the Telco\n            segment as of March 31, 2020, which fully impaired goodwill for the Telco segment. Although we do not\n            anticipate a future impairment charge, certain events could occur that might adversely affect the reported\n            value of the remaining goodwill in the Wireless segment. Such events could include, but are not limited to,\n            economic or competitive conditions, a significant change in technology, the economic condition of the\n            customers and industries we serve, and a material negative change in the relationships with one or more of\n            our significant customers or equipment suppliers. If our judgments and assumptions change as a result of the\n            occurrence of any of these events or other events that we do not currently anticipate, our expectations as\n            to future results and our estimate of the implied fair value of the Wireless segment also may change.'}}, {'@style': 'height:42.75pt;position:relative;width:100%', 'div': {'@style': 'bottom:0;position:absolute;width:100%', 'div': {'@style': 'text-align:center', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': '15'}}}}, {'@style': 'min-height:42.75pt;width:100%', 'div': {'span': {'br': None}}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:10pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Intangibles'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:10pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Intangible\n            assets that have finite useful lives are amortized on a straight-line basis over their estimated useful\n            lives ranging from 3 to 10 years. Intangible assets are also tested for impairment when events and\n            circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable. Due to our continued operating losses\n            and the uncertainties surrounding the COVID-19 pandemic on the overall economy and the resulting impact on\n            our Company, we determined that there were indicators for us to test our intangible assets for impairment at\n            March 31, 2020. It was determined that we needed to perform a specific fair value assessment for each of the\n            intangible assets at both Nave and Triton as their individual undiscounted forecasted cash flows did not\n            exceed their respective carrying values. We then performed a fair value assessment of each of the intangible\n            assets and compared them to the individual carrying value amounts at March 31, 2020. As a result of this\n            assessment, we recorded an impairment charge of $3.9 million related to the customer relationship\n            intangibles in the Telco segment as of March 31, 2020. As of September\xa030, 2020, there were no further\n            indicators of impairment.'}}, {'span': {'br': None}}, {'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Impairment\n            of Long-Lived Assets'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:10pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'The\n            Company reviews long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that\n            the asset’s carrying amount may not be recoverable.\xa0 The Company conducts its long-lived asset\n            impairment analyses in accordance with Accounting Standards Codification (“ASC”) 360-10-15,\n            “Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets.”\xa0 ASC 360-10-15 requires the Company to group\n            assets and liabilities at the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of the\n            cash flows of other assets and liabilities and evaluate the asset group against the sum of the undiscounted\n            future cash flows.\xa0 If the undiscounted cash flows do not indicate the carrying amount of the asset is\n            recoverable, an impairment charge is measured as the amount by which the carrying amount of the asset group\n            exceeds its fair value based on discounted cash flow analysis or appraisals. The Company recorded a $0.7\n            million impairment of a right-of-use asset in the Telco segment as of September\xa030, 2020, related to\n            vacating and partially subleasing a leased facility. Our internal control over financial reporting\n            includes those policies and procedures that (i)\xa0pertain to the maintenance of records that, in\n            reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of our assets;\n            (ii)\xa0provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of\n            financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that our receipts and\n            expenditures are being made only in accordance with authorization of our management and board of directors;\n            and (iii)\xa0provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized\n            acquisition, use or disposition of our assets that could have a material effect on our financial\n            statements.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:10pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'All\n            internal control systems, no matter how well designed, have inherent limitations. ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Organization\n                    and basis of presentation'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:10pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'The\n                    consolidated financial statements include the accounts of ADDvantage Technologies Group, Inc. and\n                    its subsidiaries, all of which are wholly owned (collectively, the “Company”).\xa0\n                    Intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation.\xa0\xa0The\n                    Company’s reportable segments are Wireless Infrastructure Services (“Wireless”)\n                    and Telecommunications (“Telco”).\xa0 The Cable Television (“Cable TV”)\n                    segment was sold on June 30, 2019, so the Company has classified the Cable TV segment as\n                    discontinued operations (see Note 4 – Discontinued Operations) in 2019.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:10pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Other\n                    reclassifications'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:10pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'The\n                    Company changed its presentation of cost of sales and operating, selling, general and administrative\n                    expenses on the unaudited consolidated condensed statements of operations. During fiscal year 2020,\n                    the Company reviewed its financial reporting of expenses in connection with its current operating\n                    segments in order to enhance the usefulness of the presentation of the Company’s expenses.\n                    Based on that review, the Company reclassified certain expenses into operating expenses for\n                    presentation purposes. Operating expenses include the indirect costs associated with operating our\n                    businesses. Indirect costs are costs that are not directly attributable to projects or products,\n                    which would include indirect personnel costs, facility costs, vehicles, insurance, communication,\n                    and business taxes, among other less significant cost categories. These costs were previously\n                    recorded in either costs of sales or operating, selling, general and administrative expenses in\n                    prior years. Additionally, the Company reclassified depreciation and amortization from operating,\n                    selling, general and administrative expenses into its own financial statement line item in the\n                    consolidated statements of operations. Selling, general and administrative expenses include overhead\n                    costs, which primarily consist of personnel costs, insurance, professional services, and\n                    communication, among other less significant cost categories. The prior year has been reclassified to\n                    conform with the current year’s presentation of costs of sales, operating expenses, selling,\n                    general and administrative expenses, and depreciation and amortization. experience, current conditions, and reasonable and supportable\n                    forecasts.\xa0Entities will now use forward-looking information to better form their credit loss\n
